items.content_html:
Summary

Remove IDB APIs which existed only in intermediate spec drafts and never appeared in any browser. Please note that IDBDatabaseException was left intact since it was technically implemented at some point in Firefox and with prefix in Chrome (even though it was removed from both).

Motivation

These APIs never existed.

Supporting details

Please look at headers on these pages which explain that these APIs were just spec drafts.

Related issues

None.

items.title: Remove sync version of IDB API which never existed

items.content_html:
Summary

Delete Glossary/DHTML

Motivation

This term is long obsolete and having it on MDN could only confuse people by implying the term is still used. Even when DHTML term was relevant, there were a few competing definitions (one is presented here).

Supporting details

N/A

items.content_html:
Part of #10337, the project to modernize the JS Learning Area.

This is the second PR that updates the final module, Client-side web APIs. It makes minor updates to the second article, Manipulating documents.

Marking as draft because this has a corresponding PR in mdn/learning-area: both PRs should be merged together, and changes in one will need corresponding changes in the other one.

But this is ready for review.

I had a question though: the page contains an exercise at https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Learn/JavaScript/Client-side_web_APIs/Manipulating_documents#active_learning_getti[…]from_the_window_object and I am wondering, would you not use vw and vh in this situation? i.e. https://codepen.io/willbamberg/pen/qBVxMLR . If so, we should remove this exercise, as it seems to be giving bad advice.
items.title: JS Learn: update client-side APIs, part 2

items.title: Update with info on AblePlayer

items.content_html:
Summary

Abstractions such as Person, Animal, Foo, Bar, Cat, and Professor don't give a proper understanding of OOP, they are widespread in books and guides for beginners, but can be never found in a real programs. Such abstraction are neither DTOs nor domain model classes, they are just tutorial examples. I propose to take programming and mathematical abstractions like Adder, Point, List, Lock, Connection, Session, Pool which can be very simple and expressive enough to show all OOP features. At the same time those abstractions are good enough to be moved with minimal corrections to the real production code. Here are examples from my university course and I believe, it works.

Metadata

  • Adds a new document
  • Rewrites (or significantly expands) a document
  • Fixes a typo, bug, or other error
items.title: Propose alternative examples for OOP

items.title: Refactored Example code.

items.content_html:
Summary

The quote from ECMA spec had a lot of redundant information that was covered in the Parameters section.
This removes redundant information and attempts to provide prose instead of pure specification.

Motivation

Reduce is very tricky for new developers. My aim is to make it easier to digest the information without sugar-coating or hiding the complexities. This follows my previous work here mdn/interactive-examples#1996

Supporting details

Prior work by other contributors: #10555

Comment by @wbamberg #10555:

I would love to replace that big quote from the spec

Related issues

Closes #12947

Metadata

  • Adds a new document
  • Rewrites (or significantly expands) a document
  • Fixes a typo, bug, or other error

Changes

  • Remove redundant information
  • Categorize spec info about edge cases and mutations.
  • Give guidance about when to not use reduce.
  • Organize examples - Moved 2 spec examples down to go with the rest of the examples.

Open questions

Do we want to have the "when not to use" section? I saw something similar exists for Array.prototype.map

How's the ordering here?
items.title: Rewrite description array.prototype.reduce

items.content_html:
Summary

Edited code examples, to convert sequence of two .then() functions, to a single one.

Motivation

According to the examples the developer can access all 'response' properties in the first .then(),
and the response.body data in the second .then(), separately.
With the suggested code the whole 'response' object is available in the first .then() block.
That is all response properties, together with the response.body.

Supporting details

Lots of developers do not use fetch API because of this exact issue.
They can not access together response properties and data in one code block.
The examples code confuses users, as it is obvious by the stackoverflow.com questions.

Related issues

Metadata

  • Adds a new document
  • Rewrites (or significantly expands) a document
  • Fixes a typo, bug, or other error
items.title: Examples code re-written with response.body stream converted to string.

items.content_html:
This changes the slug for the Array.prototype.reduce() article to Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Array/reduce, for consistency with slugs for all other Array methods — in particular, reduceRight(): Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Array/reduceRight

Below are the results of ripgrepping Global_Objects/Array slugs.

As can be seen in the results, the Array.prototype.reduce() article is the only one that doesn’t have a lowercase slug — other than the Array() constructor article, whose slug should not be lowercased.
